full_text: Screened by NARA, 9/18/2023 Form I-215B (Rev. 4-1-68) ED STATES DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE RECORD OF SWORN STATEMENT IN AFFIDAVIT FORM AFFIDAVIT IN RE: Ben Nung WONG FILE NO. 478 435 474, EXECUTED AT Los Angeles, California DATE 9/11/68 Before the following officer of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service: Loyd L. Netherlin, Investigator in the Chinese language. Interpreter J. H. Moy used. I, Ben Nung NONG acknowledge that the above-named officer has identified himself to me as an officer of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, authorized by law to administer oaths and take testimony in connection with the enforcement of the Immigration and Nationality laws of the United States. He has informed me that he desires to take my sworn statement regarding : my right to be an remain in the United States He has told me that my statement must be freely and voluntarily given and has advised me of these rights: "You have the right to remain silent. Anything you say can be used against you in court, or in any immigration or administrative proceeding. You have the right to talk to a lawyer for advice before we ask you any questions and to have him with you during questioning. If you cannot afford a lawyer, one will be appointed for you before any questioning if you wish. If you decide to answer questions now without a lawyer present, you will still have the right to stop answering at any time. You also have the right to stop answering at any time until you talk to a lawyer.' I am willing to make a statement without anyone else being present. I swear that I will tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help me, God. Being duly sworn, I make the following statement: My name is Ben Nung WONG. My immigration name is WONG Kwoek Hai, I live at 1320 W. 17th St., Los Angeles, Calif. 90006. I operate the B.W. Market at 6601 S. Main ST., Los Angeles, Calif. 90003. I was born on 12/7/15 at Ping Lok Vil., ISD., China and I am a citizen of China. My parents WONG Wee Don and HOM Gam Yip were natives and citimens of China. My father died in 1921 in the U. S. My mother remarried and is now in Canada. I first entered the U. S. at San Pedro, California on 2/24/30 as WONG Kwock Hai United States citimen son of WONG Sick Hong. I have never been inspected and admit ed to the U. S. as an alien. I never applied to an American consular official for a document as an olien. I came to the U. S. intending to remain permanently.
